title: Spending Personality Test
description: What's your spending style? Discover your money habits and financial personality!

questions.question: When you get paid, the first thing you do is...

choices.text: Transfer a set amount to savings/investment
Check fixed expenses like bills and rent
Plan what to buy and stick to it
Buy immediately if you like something
Great opportunity! Buy things you've wanted
Only buy essentials with good discounts

questions.question: Compared to friends, your spending is...

choices.text: They say I'm generous and cool
They say I'm frugal and practical
They say it depends on the situation

questions.question: When making a big purchase, you...

choices.text: Save in advance and pay in cash
Compare many options for the best price
Use installments to make it manageable
Too much hassle, don't do it
Have a rough idea of spending

questions.question: What's most important when spending money?

choices.text: Saving and investing for the future

questions.question: After an impulse purchase, you feel...
At the end of the month, your bank balance is...

choices.text: Prefer enjoying the present over goals

results.title: The Thorough Planner
results.description: You are a Thorough Planner! You prioritize saving and investing, meticulously managing your expenses. You have clear financial goals and rarely make impulse purchases. Sometimes it's okay to spend on yourself too!

results.title: The Spontaneous Spender
results.description: You are a Spontaneous Spender! You value present happiness and buy what you want immediately. Money is meant to be spent! But consider saving for the future occasionally too.

results.title: The Practical Saver
results.description: You are a Practical Saver! You value getting the best bang for your buck and only spend on necessities. You compare and analyze to make the best choices, avoiding unnecessary spending.

results.title: The Flexible Spender
results.description: You are a Flexible Spender! Your spending patterns vary depending on the situation, with no fixed rules. While adaptable, establishing more consistent financial habits could help you.
